sn22.59:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.59:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the group of five mendicants:
sn22.59:5.2: For if form was self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel form:
sn22.59:5.3: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’
sn22.59:5.4: But because form is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel form:
sn22.59:5.5: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’
sn22.59:8.2: For if this consciousness was self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel consciousness:
sn22.59:8.3: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’
sn22.59:8.4: But because consciousness is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel consciousness:
sn22.59:8.5: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’
sn22.59:9.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.59:9.3: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.59:9.5: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.59:9.6: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.59:9.13: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.59:9.15: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.59:9.16: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.59:10.1: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.59:11.1: Any kind of feeling at all …
sn22.59:12.1: Any kind of perception at all …
sn22.59:12.2: Any kind of choices at all …
sn22.59:13.1: You should truly see any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.59:14.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.59:14.4: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn22.59:14.5: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.59:15.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn22.59:15.2: Uplifted, the group of five mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
sn22.59:15.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the group of five mendicants were freed from defilements without grasping.
